_header: Gladeth ye fowls of the morwe gray
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 466; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 466.3; for Complaint of Venus see 5590.
_description: Chaucer, ‘Compleynt of Mars’ — 298 lines in rhyme royal and 9-line stanzas

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
Gladith ȝe foules of the morow gayO phebus rising among the
                    rewis rede…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…That neuer did bot al way gentilnesskithith therfore to hir
                    sum kyndness
BodArcSelB24.Facsimiles:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards, eds.  
             Chaucer, Works. Bodleian Library MS Arch Selden B.24: Facsimile
                Edition.
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1995.
BodArcSelB24.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BodFair16.First Lines:
GLadeth ye lovers on the morowe grayLoo Venus rysen amonge yow
                    rowes rede…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…that neuer did but gentilessekytheth therfor on her summe
                    kyndenesse
BodFair16.Note: Treated as a single text with 5590, which follows it.
BodFair16.Attributed Title:
Complaynt of Mars and Venus (f. 15); Here endith the complaynt of venus and
                    Mars (f. 20v)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:

         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

Furnivall,  Frederick James,

BodTan346.First Lines:
Gladeth the ye louers in the morow graylo venus risen
                    amonge you rowes rede…
BodTan346.Last Lines:
…That neuyr dide but gentillnesskitheth ther fore in her somme
                    kyndnesse
BodTan346.Note: Treated as a single text with 5590, which follows it.
BodTan346.Attributed Title:
The complaint of Mars and Venus (f. 65, added seventeenth
                    century)
BodTan346.Facsimiles:
Robinson,  Pamela. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Tanner 346: A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and Woodbridge: Boydell and Brewer, 1980.
BodTan346.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
Gladeth ye foules at the morowen graylo venus risen among yow rowes
                    rede…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…Walkyng his Cours till she hadd hi a takeAnd he praid her to
                    hast her for his sake
CamMagPep2006.Note: Ends imperfectly after stanza 12; second occurrence in MS.
CamMagPep2006.Facsimiles:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Pepys 2006: A Facsimile. Magdalen College,
                Cambridge.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and [Woodbridge, Suffolk]: Boydell and Brewer,
            1985.
CamMagPep2006.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Supplementary Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor
                Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 22, 59. London: Trübner, n.d.; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Gladeþe yee fooles of þis morowen grayLoo Venus is vysen
                    amonge youre rowes reede…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Þat neuer did but al gentylesseRydeþe on hir
                    þer fore some sykurnesse
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Loo yee louers gladeþe and comforteþe þou of þallyaunce
                    creayted bytwene þe hardy and furyous Mars þe god of armes and Venus
                    þe double goddesse of loue made by Geffrey Chaucier at þe commandement
                    of þe renomed and excellent prynce my lord þe duc John of Lancastre
                    (p. 130); Þallyance bytwene Mars and Venus (RT); Þus eondeþe here
                    þis complaint whiche some men sayne was made by my lady of York doughter to
                    þe kyng of Spaygne and my lord of huntyngdon some tyme duk of Excestre
                    (colophon, p. 139)

BLHar7333.First Lines:
Gladith yee floures on this morow greylo venus risen a mong yow
                    rowes rede…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Of al disport in which men frendly dwelleOf lufe pley and
                    benynge humbilnesse
BLHar7333.Note:
Lines 1-178 only, with column b left blank on
                    f.133v.
BLHar7333.Attributed Title:
THe broche of thebes as of the love / of mars and venus (f.
                        132vb, rubric)

Longleat258.First Lines:
…Whoo Raygneth now in blisse but VenusThat hath this worthy
                    knyght in gouernaunce…
Longleat258.Last Lines:
…That neuer dud but gentilnesseKitheth therfore in hire sume
                    kyndenesse
Longleat258.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Supplementary Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor
                Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 22, 59. London: Trübner, n.d.; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.
